Articles.Content:
I don't really know what to post here apart from: How do I make my plane fly and look like this:

So I don't have that much problem with the look, but the engine makes it frontflip every time I try to lift off.

I want to make it stock. Any clues on how to put that jet engine on top with plane being flyable?

You need to angle the engine (shift + WASDQE) so CoT is in line with CoM.

EDIT: You can make this easier by slapping stuff to the top of the enging and clipping it inside.

Edited February 7, 2014 by KvickFlygarn87

You guys know that feeling when you ask about something and then few moments later you figure something out for yourself? Yeaaaaah...

Here's what i did

Needs some tweaking but it works.

Anyway thanks for help Kvick.
Glad to see it works. I've always considered "realistic" games to be a success when they allow you to actually build something from the real world, and it works : )
Dayum, that's a sexay plane. How does she handle?

Actually, It handles pretty good. Just modified it.

With short wings it looks even better.
Haha, nice! you should put it up on the Spacecraft Exchange forum when you're done!

It's now up on Spacecraft Exchange subforum.

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/68815-Howl-Ho-126
That looks nice! I like it. I haven't made a high engine design like that yet. Sounds like a good time to get started.

To make matters easier for people searching for pics, that's the 162, not 126

Looking really nice!

Edit: I've tried to make it once and found that small structural panels work well for rear stabilizers. Of course, that makes its tail a bit heavier...

Edited February 8, 2014 by Ravenchant
My version of 162 it uses 2 tiny jets sort of on top to avoid the flipping.

I can think of two ways of doing this, the first is lowering the tail and keep the fuselage light and engines heavy to have the thrust centered like I did on my mini A-10 replica:

Or by placing the wings in a 5 to 10 degrees pitched up position so that it counteracts the pitching down caused by the engine. I built this quickly, so it is not the most maneuverable plane but it's a proof of concept:

Edited February 9, 2014 by Mr. Speed
stupid mistakes

Thank you everyone for help, but I came up with my own solution.

You can't see it on this pic, but the fuel tank with engine and air intake are attached to a tilted H-beam. The beam itself is on the cockpit, because the tail section has some problems with symmetry. That way I could experiment with the angle of thrust without touching the engine section.

And yes, I know about the 162 thing. I just had a derp moment there not remembering the actual plane name.

I love making real-world inspired planes. The best SSTO I ever made was roughly based on a P-38.

Also, FAR helps a bit in dealing with off-center thrust, but adds a bunch of other stuff to contend with.
